Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental and Theoretical Studies of the Biomechanics of Fibrin Polymer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: These Collaborative awards by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Pennsylvania and University of Massachusetts at Lowell are to investigate the mechanical behavior of the structural component of blood clots, the fibrin gel. Long-term goal project is to modify fibrin to create distinctive new biomaterials for cell and drug delivery, patterning, and tissue engineering. With this award, the researchers will study the mechanical properties of fibrin clots at the macroscopic, microscopic and submolecular levels to understand the basis of their functional behavior. A key novelty of this work is combined state-of-the-art experimental and theoretical exploration to understand the mechanical behavior of fibrin networks at these different spatial scales. This research will provide opportunities for training of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students in the highly interdisciplinary areas of nanotechnology and biophysics, with attention to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. The scientific community will be reached by organizing symposia in international conferences, and by presenting research findings regularly, as well as the NSF-funded Nano/Bio Interface Center for NanoDay and other activities targeted at minority students and teachers in nearby high schools.

Technical: The research objective of this proposal is to understand the mechanical behavior of fibrin gels with the long-term goal of modifying fibrin to create distinctive new biomaterials for cell and drug delivery, patterning, and tissue engineering. Earlier studies by the researchers have demonstrated that the remarkable extensibility of fibrin clots has its origins in the unfolding of particular domains of the fibrin molecule, with the stress-strain response of an individual fiber connected to the force-stretch dependence at the nanoscale. Researchers plan to define the molecular structural and thermodynamic basis of fibrin deformability and viscoelasticity. A key novelty of this work is combined experimental and theoretical exploration to understand the tensile behavior of fibrin networks at different spatial scales, from submolecular (atomic) to macroscopic levels. This goal will be achieved by combining state-of-the-art experimental methodology with novel Molecular Dynamics simulations and a comprehensive continuum mechanics model. This research will provide opportunities for training of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students in the highly interdisciplinary areas of nanotechnology and biophysics, with attention to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. The scientific findings will be disseminated by organizing symposia in both national and international levels. The research findings will be presented to community by attending other scientific meetings, as well as the NSF-funded Nano/Bio Interface Center for NanoDay and other activities targeting minority students and teachers in high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Heart attack and stroke continues to be one of the leading causes of death in humans in the US and abroad. There is experimental evidence pointing to the relevance of fibrin mechanics in relation to embolization. The research performed offers insights to understand and model the material properties of fibrin fibers and fibrin network. The atomic structural models of fibrin protofibrils reconstructed can be used to create atomic models of fibrin fibers that form fibrin clots and obstructive thrombi. Thesed models will help to elucidate the atomic level details of complex structure and function of fibrin network on multiple spatial scales. Better understanding of fibrin structure and mechanics is important to understand thrombosis in vivo. Our results will lead to the design of new approaches and strategies to treat bleeding and thrombosis. This will help to improve the human health and to reduce the risks of heart attack and stroke. The research performed was focused on the mechanics of fibrin networks, including blood clots and thrombi. This might open the door for systematic manipulation and design of fibrin based biomaterials which have found broad application as tissue engineering scaffolds and as glues and sealants used in surgery. Our results could also find application in the diagnosis of blood diseases. Fibrin gels could potentially lead beyond a purely academic interest, since large volume changes and high compliances associated with this unique biomaterial have parallels with electroactive gels. The research performed illuminated novel aspect of mechanics of fibrin-derived biopolymers, which resulted in the development of new continuum theories (for the alpha-to-beta phase transition in proteins), stochastic reaction-diffusion models (Fluctuating Bottleneck model for the transition from "catch bonds" to "slip bonds" in biomolecular complexes, Fluctuating Nonlinear Spring model of mechanical deformation of biological particles), advanced computational techniques (Dynamic Force Spectroscopy in silico, Langevin dynamics in implicit solvent with hydrodynamic interactions), and high-performace computing on GPUs. These approaches can now be implemented to address basic science and engineering aspects of emerging biomaterials.

 

Broader impacts: Research activities provided multiple opportunities for training of graduate and undergraduate students in the highly interdisciplinary areas of computational biology, nanotechnology and biophysics. Students were involved in i) setting up and running Molecular Dynamics simulations on GPUs, ii) learning CUDA language for GPU computing; iii)  force field parameterization, iv) manipulating with crystal structures of fibrin and its smaller fragments; and v) molecular docking. Students learned new theories, including vi) Abeyaratne-Knowles formulation of phase transitions; vii) Zwanzig-type Fluctuating Bottleneck model; and viii) Fluctuating Nonlinear Spring model. Students actively participated in software development for calculation of ix) Cauchy stress tensor; and x) hydrodynamic interactions in biological processes; and xi) webpage development. Graduate students participated in workshops on GPU computing. The PI delivered invited talks at the international conferences, in addition to invited seminars with the industry partners highlighting the importance of computer based modeling. The PI hosted an (Asian American female  ) high school student, who received an award at the Massachusetts State Science and Engineering Fair based on results of computer simulations performed in PI's lab. The simulation data, atomic models, computational approaches and theoretical models developed in this project were made available to other scientists. The PI developed new graduate and undergraduate courses (Quantum Chemistry, Computational Biochemistry), and added a Machine Learning module to the graduate/undergraduate course (Computational Biochemistry).

 

Brief Summary: Structure and mechanics of blood clots and thrombi affect the course and outcomes of thrombotic disorders. We performed combined experimental exploration and computational studies of the mechanical response of fibrin networks at different spatial scales. Coupling the experimental and computational approaches was a major strength of the project. The more specific goals of this proposal were: 1) to build supramolecular fibrin structures to probe their tensile deformation and molecular unfolding; 2) to elucidate the molecular structural basis for the tensile deformation of fibrin networks using small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), high-resolution AFM imaging, and MD simulations; 3) to develop analytical tools to understand and predict fibrin mechanical properties. We performed a number of research activities to understand structural alterations and changes in mechanical behavior of fibrin network on multiple scles of length from nanometers (fibrin monomers) to micrometers (fibrin protofibrils) and to millimeters (fibrin fibers), and time (from nanoseconds to milliseconds). The long-term goal of this project was generating new knowledge to enable researchers to modify the fibrin structure and composition in order to create distinctive new materials. We based our computational approach on defining the structural, kinetic and thermodynamic basis of fibrin deformability and viscoelasticity. All of the proposed research activities were completed. The computational methods, theoretical models and atomic structures were successfully validated by the experimental measurements.   The results obtained will have a major impact by providing a basis for generating fibrin-related materials for various biomaterials applications in cell and drug delivery, patterning, and tissue engineering.
